utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Oh. How the...

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, I guess it would be nice, if I could touch your body, I know not everybody has got a body like you. Baaby.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You know, most people go for the hardwood or carpeting. I think guitars and garbage work just as well.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Got the urge to play last night. Had to go all the way back to my apartment. Thought I'd save on future trips.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Hmm. That's very eco-friendly of you. How about keeping down on the noise pollution?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: 6:33. You should be flossing by now.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I'm not going to work today. I'm going hunting. After I sleep in.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Ah. Ah.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Is it that time of year again? He's a self-important jerk.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: He's my friend.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He's a self-important jerk.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Seems to be what I'm attracted to.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Guy calls you Jim. Doesn't even know your name.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Jim is short for James. Now go away, Lim.

utterance.speaker: Tucker
utterance.content: Nice shot, Jim.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Oh, yeah. Oh yeah. I nailed that tree. Maple syrup for dinner. We should have got a guide.

utterance.speaker: Tucker
utterance.content: Oh, doesn't count as new adventure if you have someone holding your hand.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: On the other hand, we are holding weapons and have no idea what we're doing. Fun.

utterance.speaker: Tucker
utterance.content: We need to sneak up on them. I read somewhere that the Native Americans say turkeys know what you're thinking.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: So I should stop thinking about German porn.

utterance.speaker: Tucker
utterance.content: No, no. That'll lure them closer.

utterance.speaker: Tucker
utterance.content: We're terrible at this.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Yeah. Well, at least it's cold and my new boots leak.

utterance.speaker: Tucker
utterance.content: Well, it's almost time anyway. Did you bring the bag?

utterance.speaker: Tucker
utterance.content: May 30, 2004, 10:07 a.m. Dr. Wilson informed me that if treatment didn't go well, my leukemia would give me only six more months to live. November 30, 2004, six months later, I didn't die. As long as I am alive, I will find new and exciting ways to thank you for giving me another year. Now move very, very far away from there so that I can be sure and thank you again next year.

utterance.speaker: Tucker
utterance.content: Thanks, Jim.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: All right, let's see how many more turkeys we can miss.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Yeah, this will work.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: What the hell?

utterance.speaker: Tucker
utterance.content: God. Sorry, I don't know what happened. I can't move my arm. Am I having a stroke?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I don't know.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Good news. Head CT doesn't show any signs of a stroke.

utterance.speaker: Ashley
utterance.content: So he's gonna be okay, right?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I cannot believe how much you've grown up in five years. She's... She's not Emily.

utterance.speaker: Tucker
utterance.content: Ashley, my girlfriend. New life, new adventures. Ashley, meet Jim.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: It's good to meet you.

utterance.speaker: Ashley
utterance.content: So this arm thing, does that mean his leukemia's back?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I checked blood counts and blood cell morphologies. Everything is normal.

utterance.speaker: Ashley
utterance.content: So these blood tests, it means it's not cancer for sure.

utterance.speaker: Tucker
utterance.content: He said I'm fine.

utterance.speaker: Ashley
utterance.content: So what do you think it is?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Hopefully something innocuous. There's a doctor I can speak to who's great... who's great at diagnosing...

utterance.speaker: Ashley
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Sorry, that cold sore, how long have you had that?

utterance.speaker: Ashley
utterance.content: Um, two weeks. I'm sorry. I-I got the call. I didn't have time to cover it up.

utterance.speaker: Tucker
utterance.content: What is it, Jim?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: That cold sore is caused by a virus. Assuming you guys kiss, the virus could transfer, infect your spine, and cause the paralysis. It's a disease called Transverse Myelitis.

utterance.speaker: Tucker
utterance.content: And is that good news or bad news?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: It's great news. I'll get you a room and start you on Acyclovir.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I just had a House moment. Diagnosed Transverse Myelitis from a cold sore. How cool is that? Patients really eat that crap up.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It's why I'm loved. What am I doing here?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Ultrasound is clear.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Which means he's definitely not pregnant, right?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: No gall stones. Could be Diverticulitis. Have you eaten any seeds?

utterance.speaker: Juan
utterance.content: I'm joining you, Antonio Aguilar. We'll play in God's Mariachi band.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Draw some blood. The self-important jerk does not have Transverse Myelitis. He's got cancer.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: How do you even--

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Okay. Maybe I paid the redhead down in records a few bucks to CC me on all your cases. A few patients die, you might get sad again. Make a speech that would end your career. Frankly, I'm stalking you for you. How long does a simple blood draw take?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Almost finished.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, when you're finished almost finishing it, test it.

utterance.speaker: Juan
utterance.content: Mi estomago's ripped open by the hand of God. He spilled my blood.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Confusion. Delirium.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why rule out the hand of God so fast?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Your guy's low white count and right arm paralysis equals a recurrence of his leukemia. Simple math.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Did you look past the first page of the file? No AML cells anywhere. I did the blood smears myself.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It's still cancer. You know how I know? He's got an oncologist for a doctor.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: And your magical leukemia detector is more powerful than a flow cytometer?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I look for zebras because other doctors rule out all the horses. In this case, you are those other doctors. You haven't earned a zebra. 100 bucks.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Are you serious?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Look, friends don't diagnose friends with cancer. I get it. Your problem is you're not objective. Your caring is clouding your diagnosis. Just cut that out and you could be a pretty decent doctor.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Just give me the lactic acid level.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The fact that you can't speak English is not an excuse for you not being humiliated by what I'm about to say. It's also not an excuse for you not telling us that you were a tennis pro. If you had, we wouldn't have wasted our time.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Fine. 100 bucks.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Is Tucker settling in?

utterance.speaker: Sandy
utterance.content: Yeah. Already got his first dose of Acyclovir. And don't worry, I ordered his girlfriend the kiddy meal.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Hoo-ah. Next patient on deck.

utterance.speaker: Sandy
utterance.content: Del Clinton, day six of chemo. You just missed the grandkids.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Oh, that's all right. Last time they were here, they painted my tie.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You're almost ready to go home. You feeling okay?

utterance.speaker: Del
utterance.content: I feel like I felt after the last four rounds.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: In oncology, familiar pain means all is well.

utterance.speaker: Del
utterance.content: So that's good, right?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Yeah. I heard Jesse and Zeke were by earlier.

utterance.speaker: Del
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Sorry Del, I gotta run.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: How are they doing?

utterance.speaker: Del
utterance.content: They--they're fine.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: No game-winning hits? No aced report cards? No school plays?

utterance.speaker: Del
utterance.content: I guess not. I thought you had to go.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Are you depressed?

utterance.speaker: Del
utterance.content: I have cancer.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You've had cancer for a long time. It's never stopped you from bragging about the grandkids.

utterance.speaker: Del
utterance.content: I guess I'm feeling a little more down than usual. Can you give me something?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Yeah. I don't want you to get alarmed, but sometimes depression can be a sign that something else is going on. I'm just gonna order a couple of extra tests. Okay?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: What's going on?

utterance.speaker: Ashley
utterance.content: It's his foot now.

utterance.speaker: Tucker
utterance.content: It's nothing.

utterance.speaker: Ashley
utterance.content: It's not nothing.

utterance.speaker: Tucker
utterance.content: I just started getting a little tingling feeling in my foot.

utterance.speaker: Ashley
utterance.content: Is that bad?

utterance.speaker: Tucker
utterance.content: Ashley, it's gonna be okay.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: It might mean his foot fell asleep. It might mean nothing. Could you give us a few minutes?

utterance.speaker: Ashley
utterance.content: What--why can't you tell me?

utterance.speaker: Tucker
utterance.content: Because you're making him nervous. Just give us a few minutes, okay, hon?

utterance.speaker: Tucker
utterance.content: Does this mean that it's not the disease you thought it was?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: It means the medicine I gave you is not working. I just might have to hit it harder. I'm going to add Ribavirin to your treatment.

utterance.speaker: Tucker
utterance.content: Jim, are you sure that this isn't a recurrence?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: So the brave face is just for Ashley.

utterance.speaker: Tucker
utterance.content: She's young. She's terrified. She's not really equipped.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Don't worry. Once you've had cancer, recurrence is your biggest fear. I get it. I've looked at this thing every which way there is. That's not

utterance.speaker: Tucker
utterance.content: Can you call my daughter and ask her to come down?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You can't do it?

utterance.speaker: Tucker
utterance.content: She hasn't exactly been talking to me since I got together with Ashley. I'd really like her to be here.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Of course.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Exactly how serious does it have to be to justify you coming to see your father? No. I'm sorry. I just--I'd rather you regretted coming than regretted not coming. Thanks Emily.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: How's Tucker?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Oh, well, he's made a mess of his personal life. But physically, I think he's gonna be fine. Transverse Myelitis.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: What does House think?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: What is this? Is House my overseer now?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: No, it's just not always a good idea for doctors to treat their friends, that's all.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Well, House has got 100 bucks on cancer. So unless you want in

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Um, is Bonnie still a realtor?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: As far as I know.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Do you mind if I call her? I'm, uh, looking for a new place. I'm moving in with Lucas.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: it wasn't the tennis.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You're moving in with Lucas?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Yes.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You're Bonnie's friend. You know how to reach her. And yet instead of calling her, you come and seek my permission. You want my blessing, and implicitly, House's blessing.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I don't need House's blessing.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Good.

utterance.speaker: Ashley
utterance.content: So when will he be able to move his arm again?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Should be soon.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Started smoking again?

utterance.speaker: Tucker
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Ashley
utterance.content: What--what does that mean? Is it bad that he's coughing?

utterance.speaker: Emily
utterance.content: Hi, dad.

utterance.speaker: Melissa
utterance.content: Hey

utterance.speaker: Tucker
utterance.content: Melissa, hey. I didn't know you were coming.

utterance.speaker: Emily
utterance.content: I was at Mom's house when Dr. Wilson called.

utterance.speaker: Melissa
utterance.content: I can go if it's gonna be weird.

utterance.speaker: Tucker
utterance.content: No, no. Stay. It's fine.

utterance.speaker: Melissa
utterance.content: Hi.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: How are you?

utterance.speaker: Melissa
utterance.content: Is he okay?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Yeah. He's okay. I'm not a big fan of this coughing though.

utterance.speaker: Melissa
utterance.content: You must be Ashley.

utterance.speaker: Ashley
utterance.content: Hi. Hey, are you okay?

utterance.speaker: Ashley
utterance.content: Do you think this cold sore thing could've caused this?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: No. Whatever's causing this is affecting more than his nerves. I need a crash cart in here!

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Don't you guys have a dying Mexican crooner to attend to?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: He isn't dying anymore. Found out he was on a popcorn diet. Eating ten bags of microwave popcorn a day. Huffing the fumes scarred his lungs.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Wow, that's... very strange. Where's House?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Performing his ritual "hiding from Cuddy to avoid getting a new case" dance. It's sort of a jazz-fusion type of thing.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: He's probably eating lunch in the morgue. I can page him to your office if you want.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Actually... maybe it would be better if I talked to you guys alone. House and I have a bet about one of my patients. You guys mind making him 100 bucks poorer?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: 43-year-old male in remission from leukemia presents with left arm paralysis and trouble breathing.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I assume House's money is on cancer.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Thanks. That's very helpful.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Subdural hematoma would explain--

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: CT ruled it out. I thought it was TM, so I started him on antivirals, but he got worse.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Bacterial infection?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Bacteria would move much faster than this. He'd be dead already.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Could be fungal.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Fungal infection would explain his breathing problem, but not his "unable to move his arm" problem.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Actually, if aspergillus fungus balls took root in his lungs and spread to his spine, it would explain both. Thanks.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: The treatment involves riddling the infected area with bb-sized pellets of antifungal meds.

utterance.speaker: Tucker
utterance.content: I assume you don't just load up the 12-gauge and pepper me with birdshot.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: No. We have a slightly more humane delivery system. But we do have to open you up. It is surgery. And like any operation, there are risks.

utterance.speaker: Tucker
utterance.content: What do you think, honey?

utterance.speaker: Ashley
utterance.content: I-I don't know. I mean, is surgery really such a good idea? He just seems so sick. I just— you should do whatever you think is best.

utterance.speaker: Melissa
utterance.content: Is this the only way to go after this thing?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Because of the rapid progression, I don't think we have time to test or try IVs.

utterance.speaker: Melissa
utterance.content: And he's strong enough to endure anesthesia.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Definitely.

utterance.speaker: Melissa
utterance.content: I want you there during the surgery.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Of course.

utterance.speaker: Melissa
utterance.content: You gotta do it.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Good. Dr. Chase will be in here soon to get you set for the OR.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Page Dr. Chase to Tucker's room for a surgery consult. And can you get me--

utterance.speaker: Sandy
utterance.content: Uh, Mr. Koplovitz wants to talk to you.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Is everything all right?

utterance.speaker: Sandy
utterance.content: He wanted to talk to his doctor, not his doctor's assistant. Oh, and House is looking for you.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: What did you tell him?

utterance.speaker: Sandy
utterance.content: That you were in the clinic. I figure that gives you about ten minutes. Here. Mr. Koplovitz's chart. Go.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Hello, Saul. I heard you were looking for me.

utterance.speaker: Saul
utterance.content: I'm very tired. But I can't sleep.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Today's your lucky day. I happen to be a sleep specialist.

utterance.speaker: Saul
utterance.content: Thanks, Doc.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Hey. Can a guy get a little privacy?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Nice hiding spot.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Actually, it's perfect. It allows me to hide from Cuddy and find you. What did she want?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: She was checking up on Tucker thanks to you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That's it?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Like what? Something about you? Something you could interpret as being about you? An anagram maybe? It'd be great if you could play hide and seek somewhere else. My patient--

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No problem. Just give me the 100 bucks you owe me and I'm gone.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Tucker doesn't have cancer.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He doesn't have a ball of fungus in his lungs either. Next time you want to use my team, I suggest you at least leave a tip.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I'm late for surgery.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Ah, your assistant said you'd be in here. I talked to Bonnie.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Let's take this outside. Mr. Koplovitz just got to sleep.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Oh, sorry. She found us this fantastic loft.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Outside.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I mean, it's not a loft really, it's just more urban. Not that I'm urban,

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Procedure should take about an hour. I'll be observing the entire time.

utterance.speaker: Tucker
utterance.content: Thanks. Maybe it'd be better if you stayed with Ashley. She's more scared than I am.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Well, she's... at her age... she's not supposed to be dealing with issues of life and death.

utterance.speaker: Tucker
utterance.content: Wasn't what I was planning when I went after her.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Why did you leave Melissa?

utterance.speaker: Tucker
utterance.content: We got married young. We... I'm not sure.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: There's nothing to talk about.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why are you doing surgery when I need you finding me a new case?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: You don't want a new case.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh, right. Guess I'm here for Wilson. Obviously you didn't tell me that Cuddy was moving in with Lucas 'cause you were protecting me. Which is odd since I told you that I'm fine with their relationship. So obviously, you question one of those assumptions or you have an issue with logic.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Yes, you're fine with them dating. But moving in together is a whole other level of commitment.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: This is the 21st century, Wilson. I realize that the logical course of any adult relationship could one day lead to fornication. Although, the fact that she wants to buy a loft, could actually mean that their relationship is not as serious as I thought.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Oh, for God's sake, House, don't do this to yourself. It's a loft. It has no deeper meaning than open-space living arrangement.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If you bought into her diatribe about rediscovering her lost city girl roots. And two bedrooms. It just reeks of commitment issues.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Yeah. Or she has a baby.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: This is classic mid-life Cuddy crisis. This is her version of a two-seat convertible.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Yep, clearly you're fine with it.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Wilson, he's got global lung damage. Means it's not fungal. It's PCP pneumonia.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Hmm. Obviously something is knocking out his immune system. Three options. HIV, acquired SCID, or my personal favorite, cancer. I'm sure you'll test for all three.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: 62-year-old African-American man with lymphoma now in remission. I did a CT and found a small lesion on the upper lobe of his left lung.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: During a routine follow-up, I realized the patient was depressed.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Thanks. The treatment indicate--

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh, I'm sorry. I didn't realize you were in the middle of something.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: It's a conference room, with glass walls. You thought I'd be alone?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Your patient has cancer. Not that guy. Who probably also has cancer. And he's probably also your buddy. Thought you'd want to know. And you owe me 100 bucks.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You have acute lymphoblastic leukemia. A.L.L.

utterance.speaker: Melissa
utterance.content: So, it is a recurrence.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: No. It's different. It's a second leukemia. Probably caused by the chemotherapy we gave him five years ago.

utterance.speaker: Tucker
utterance.content: That's why you didn't see it. Maybe they can rename it ironic leukemia.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: This is not the end. Tests show that the cancer is limited to your brain. That's good news.

utterance.speaker: Ashley
utterance.content: How can cancer in his head be good news?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: The blood-brain barrier separates the blood in your head from the blood in your body. Keeps the cancer bottled up. We can go for a cure.

utterance.speaker: Melissa
utterance.content: So give me the numbers. What are we looking at?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: 90% chance of cure.

utterance.speaker: Melissa
utterance.content: Really. What if we're in the 10%?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Steady decline. But six months of a good quality life.

utterance.speaker: Emily
utterance.content: Does he have to go through another bone marrow transplant?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: No. Chemotherapy. We can go at this with drugs alone.

utterance.speaker: Melissa
utterance.content: When do we get started?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: We begin by surgically planting a shunt so we can get the drugs directly into your brain. I already booked the OR.

utterance.speaker: Tucker
utterance.content: You're the only one who can make cancer sound like good news.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: We get it out of your head and you walk out of here, paralysis gone and cancer-free.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: We also need you to sign a health care proxy. If something goes wrong in surgery, someone needs to be appointed to make decisions for you.

utterance.speaker: Ashley
utterance.content: What are the chances of that happening?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Very remote.

utterance.speaker: Tucker
utterance.content: I think maybe Melissa should be my proxy.

utterance.speaker: Ashley
utterance.content: What? No.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Coming through. House got a new case.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Revised OR schedule. Sorry, Wilson, had to bump you. It's not like your guy's bleeding out of his eyes.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: House, your guy's not bleeding out of his eyes either.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The nurse who books the OR thinks he is.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Your case is no more urgent than mine.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, but you're way more patient.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: It's okay. You can talk about the--the paperwork in the prep area.

utterance.speaker: Ashley
utterance.content: You trust her more than me.

utterance.speaker: Tucker
utterance.content: About this, yes. You've been through the good stuff, but Melissa's been to hell and back with me. She gives me the best shot of getting through this.

utterance.speaker: Ashley
utterance.content: You still love her.

utterance.speaker: Tucker
utterance.content: Don't be silly. I love you. Please... don't make this into more than it is.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Okay, anything?

utterance.speaker: Tucker
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Can you feel this?

utterance.speaker: Tucker
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: How about here?

utterance.speaker: Tucker
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Where is everybody?

utterance.speaker: Tucker
utterance.content: Melissa and Emily went downstairs to get some breakfast.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Ashley?

utterance.speaker: Tucker
utterance.content: She had work to do.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I thought she was off today.

utterance.speaker: Tucker
utterance.content: Well, she didn't really have work to do. She was just pissed so she pretended to have work to do. I let her pretend.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Okay. Move your fingers.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: The chemo's not working.

utterance.speaker: Tucker
utterance.content: Does that mean it's not cancer?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: No. It means the chemo from your first round of treatment has made the leukemia resistant.

utterance.speaker: Tucker
utterance.content: So I'm in the 10% that don't get cured.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Maybe not.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: We just removed a screw from a guy's lung. And the weird thing is he didn't get better. Any idea what that means?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: It means you're not listening to me.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No. It means I'm ignoring you to make a point. There is a difference.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: The problem with that technique is I have no idea what point you're making.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That your idea is implicitly not worth responding to. Doubling your patient's chemo dose is stupid. Damn, now it's explicit.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: It could swamp out the resistance of the cancer cells.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The fact that it theoretically should work doesn't make it any less stupid.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Of course it does. It's exactly what you would do.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I'm me. You're you.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: And a table is a table.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And chemo is poison. And double chemo is double poison. And I can handle it when things go wrong. You can't. And things could go very,

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I can handle it.

utterance.speaker: Tucker
utterance.content: Sounds pretty dangerous.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: It is.

utterance.speaker: Tucker
utterance.content: What do you think, Mel?

utterance.speaker: Melissa
utterance.content: I think you should call Ashley.

utterance.speaker: Tucker
utterance.content: You're my family. I'm sorry I forgot that.

utterance.speaker: Emily
utterance.content: I think that you should try, whatever could keep you with us longer.

utterance.speaker: Melissa
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: Emily
utterance.content: Look.

utterance.speaker: Tucker
utterance.content: I can move them.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Hey!

utterance.speaker: Melissa
utterance.content: Thank you.

utterance.speaker: Tucker
utterance.content: What is it, Jim?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I'm gonna need to run some tests.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Intraepidermal superficial bullae. Could be pemphigus.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Or it could be from the fire.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Either way, he's dead. We can't stop the oozing.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Don't care. I'm here because it's 1:15 and Wilson started testing at 12:45. Which means...

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: The cancer's gone. But over half his hepatocytes are dead.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: In only 24 hours?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: He needs a new liver.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Look on the bright side. You can publish the results of this case study. No one will ever double the dose again.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: The double dose of chemo got rid of your cancer. But, it also trashed your liver. If I don't find you a new liver, you've only got about 24 hours left.

utterance.speaker: Emily
utterance.content: So what do we do now?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Your father's been moved to the top of the transplant list. But, all we really can do is wait.

utterance.speaker: Melissa
utterance.content: That's it? We wait? Tell me something that I can do.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I'm sorry, Mel. You and Emily don't match Tuck's blood type. And neither does Ashley. So a live liver donation is out. The best thing to do is just what you've been doing. Be together.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Hope he already told you that you're gonna die. 'Cause it's gonna make what I'm about to say a lot more relevant.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: House, I know it's raining out there in the hallway, but—

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I was just in the ER, testing my patient for autonomic dysfunction. It's the only department with a shower big enough for the whole team, plus the cardiac monitors, plus me. Anyway, relevant part, we're just wheeling the guy out, trauma came in. Motorcycle versus semi.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: How bad?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Bad for the motorcycle. Good for your liver. Blood type's a match.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Why wasn't I paged?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Because there's a problem. No organ donor card. Dead guy's sister

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Where is she?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: 20 minutes away.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: How do you get the call that your brother's dead and then run out the door? "Oh--oh--oh, that reminds me, I-I had dry cleaning to pick up."

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Did Cuddy buy the place?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Not yet. You okay?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Just making conversation. Yours was getting boring.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: What are you planning?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I'm not planning anything.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: And I don't believe you. How are you gonna punish her for dating Lucas?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Okay, now this conversation is getting boring.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Are you really okay?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No! I am not okay. Not even close.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Wow. Okay. See, that's very adult of you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, it isn't. It's just me accepting the fact that there's nothing I can do and moving on.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Which is, I think, the definition of adulthood.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, if it is, being a kid is a lot more fun.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Showtime.

utterance.speaker: Aikoa Tanaka
utterance.content: I didn't speak to him for years. But when my parents died, at their funeral, we made peace. Our parents must've blessed it.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: And I'm sure they would want him to do good with his last act in this world.

utterance.speaker: Aikoa Tanaka
utterance.content: They wanted us to be friends. Our relationship wasn't strong, but it was growing. If I allow you to defile his body, it will destroy that bond. The Itai will be harmed.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: It will save my patient's life.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What if I told you that he wasn't dead?

utterance.speaker: Aikoa Tanaka
utterance.content: Are you saying my brother is still alive?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I'm saying you're being an idiot. But I don't have time to talk you out of your religion so I'm stuck with giving you a technicality that will let you justify

utterance.speaker: Aikoa Tanaka
utterance.content: Then I'm not defiling a dead body.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: House.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The last generous act of a living person.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: House, it's too late. The liver’s started to degrade. It's no longer viable for transplant.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well played. Religion just killed another person.

utterance.speaker: Tucker
utterance.content: It's not fair, Jim. You just helped me get my family back together. I'm--I'm not ready. I would've had six more months with them if you hadn't given me that extra chemo. Now I have less than one day.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I'm sorry. We knew the risks.

utterance.speaker: Tucker
utterance.content: I don't want to lose them again. I can't lose them again.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: There's nothing more we can do.

utterance.speaker: Tucker
utterance.content: Five years ago, when I needed a transfusion, you used your own blood. We have the same type. Which means you can give me a part of your liver.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I'm your doctor.

utterance.speaker: Tucker
utterance.content: You're my friend. Should I die because you're also my doctor?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Of course not.

utterance.speaker: Tucker
utterance.content: Fine then, you're fired. Now you're just my friend. Now you can do what's right.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Tucker, it's... I can't.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Late night with the Pigeon sisters?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Every now and again, I'd like to come home without getting interrogated.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Someone's cranky. And late. Where were you?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: getting a drink. What--why are all my frozen dinners thawing on the counter?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I needed room for my margarita jello shots. I used test tubes as bottles so they'll be shaped like my cane.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why'd you go out drinking alone when you got such great company here?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Tucker wants me to donate a lobe of my liver to him.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And you were out drinking. So you're actually considering this?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Yeah. I was out marinating my liver in alcohol to get it ready for the transplant. Yeah.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Your mouth says no, but your pathetic attempt at a deflection has guilt written all over it.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: It's my fault. It is my fault! I gave him too much chemo.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You cured his cancer.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: And killed him in the process.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Quibbles.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He's had a predictable complication. Surprise. Bad things happen to people who are sick. Doesn't make you responsible.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Oh, no--not legally. Ethically. Ethically!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: A table is a table. Don't be a doormat, Wilson.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Boy, you are-- you willfully ruined my food and have taken over my living room because you already think I'm a doormat! You know what... you're wrong. Clean up your stuff and get out. You're wrong.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: How's Tucker?

utterance.speaker: Sandy
utterance.content: Um, still not dancing. But scans came in on Del Clinton. It's good news.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Thanks. Let me know as soon as Tucker takes a turn for the worse. I want to be there.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: See that small spot at the top of the lung? That was then. This is now. Spot's gone.

utterance.speaker: Del
utterance.content: That tiny little spot, huh?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Yeah. It's not too impressive, is it?

utterance.speaker: Del
utterance.content: That little dot could've killed me?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Yeah. Fortunately, we caught it early. It's gonna be okay.

utterance.speaker: Del
utterance.content: That's amazing. You got all this off me not talking about my grandkids.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Thanks, Bonnie. Just gonna have to sit tight for awhile. Okay. I put an offer on the loft. Seller turned me down. I offered exactly what a similar unit sold for three months ago.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I want to donate a lobe of my liver to Tucker.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: That's insane.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I'm donating a small portion of--

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You have hundreds of patients.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: And until I run out of excess organs, why shouldn't I do everything I can to help them?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Because you're a doctor, not a donor.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Why did you make me the head of oncology?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Not because you have the most organs. You're thoughtful, caring.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Yeah, caring. By your own criteria, a strength and not a weakness.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: This is coming out of guilt.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: This is coming out of friendship. I have a friend

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Okay.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Call me a doormat-- get it all out of your system-- but I'm doing it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: He's my friend.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I'm your friend. All the pain pills I've taken. What if I need your liver?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Right. How selfish of me not to have considered your possible future needs.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: They're all dying. They're all your friends.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I'm not here for an argument, House.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, right, that's room 12A. So why are you here? Want to make sure that I’ve called the moving van?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: No. The operation is in two hours, and I'd like you to be there with me.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: What-- why?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Because if you die, I'm alone.

utterance.speaker: Tucker
utterance.content: Thanks, Jim.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: How you feeling?

utterance.speaker: Tucker
utterance.content: Can't complain, considering if it weren't for you, I'd be dead--twice. You?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I feel good. Sending out your laundry?

utterance.speaker: Tucker
utterance.content: Going to rehab. Some place up in Katonah.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Up by your new house, not near your old house.

utterance.speaker: Tucker
utterance.content: Easier on Ashley.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I see.

utterance.speaker: Tucker
utterance.content: I was thrilled to get the family back together and Melissa's great

utterance.speaker: Ashley
utterance.content: Hi, Jim.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Actually, it's James.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You ready to admit that he's a self-important jerk?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I still feel good about what I did.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You don't feel angry?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Ah. I'm a little disappointed.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Disappointment is anger for wimps. You don't have to be so gentle about everything. It's okay to get angry once in a while.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You can't change a table.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Actually, you can. Just need a coat of paint and the guts to use it.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Bonnie.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Bonnie told me what Cuddy bid.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You're gonna outbid her?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: We do need a bigger refrigerator. She hurt my friend. She should be punished.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You got mad. I'm proud of you. Cuddy won't share that sentiment. How are you gonna explain it to her?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I'm changing our address to a P.O. box.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She'll find out eventually.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: A problem delayed is a problem denied.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Bonnie. I'll take it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Baby steps.
